posts.title: Canada's Immigration Rules Clarified - Deemed Rehabilitation Not Automatic
posts.description: In a recent ruling that's set to impact immigration procedures in Canada, the Federal Court has clarified that visa officers are not...
posts.author: GGI
posts.body:
In a recent ruling that's set to impact immigration procedures in Canada, the Federal Court has clarified that visa officers are not obliged to consider whether an individual with a criminal record is deemed rehabilitated unless the applicant explicitly requests it.

In the case of Bello v. Canada (Citizenship and Immigration), the applicant, Ms. Bello, a Nigerian citizen, had previously used a falsified passport to enter England, leading to her arrest, charges, and conviction in the United Kingdom in 2010 for using forged documents.

Fast forward to 2017, Ms. Bello, accompanied by her two minor children, claimed refugee protection in Canada. In 2019, her inadmissibility to Canada based on serious criminality was established.

In 2021, while her refugee claim was ongoing, Ms. Bello applied for permanent residence, acknowledging her inadmissibility but requesting an exemption on humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) grounds.

The visa officer rejected her application, citing serious criminality due to her foreign conviction. The key question before the Court was whether the officer's decision was reasonable.

Ms. Bello contended that the officer erred by not considering whether she was deemed rehabilitated. However, the Court ruled that her 'deemed rehabilitated' argument was not presented to the officer. She had conceded her inadmissibility and sought an 'exemption' or 'waiver'. not a determination of deemed rehabilitation.

The implications are clear: if an applicant is criminally inadmissible to Canada due to serious criminality, the onus is on the applicant to explicitly request a deemed rehabilitation determination in their application. Otherwise, it will not be considered.

Navigating Criminal Inadmissibility to Canada

For individuals facing criminal inadmissibility to Canada, there are avenues to explore:

  1. Temporary Resident Permit (TRP):A TRP grants temporary access to Canada when the benefits of entry outweigh the risks to Canadian society. It can be granted for up to three years, depending on the reason for entry, and can be applied for at any time, even before completing a criminal sentence.

  2. Criminal Rehabilitation Application: This option permanently clears past criminal history for the purpose of entering Canada. A successful application removes inadmissibility, eliminating the need for a TRP. To be eligible, the following criteria must be met:

    • The act committed abroad must be equivalent to a Canadian Criminal Code offence.
    • The applicant must have been convicted or admitted to committing the act.
    • A minimum of five years must have passed since completing the sentence.

  3. Legal Opinion Letter: Prepared by a Canadian immigration lawyer, this preemptive measure helps individuals convicted of a crime avoid inadmissibility. It outlines the legal consequences of the conviction for Canadian immigration purposes and provides insights into how different outcomes (conviction, sentencing, etc.) may affect eligibility for entry into Canada.

Stay informed as Canada's immigration landscape evolves, and remember, when facing criminal inadmissibility, clarity in your application is key to your success.

posts.title: Supreme Court Ruling Shapes Immigration Law
posts.description: Canada, September 27, 2023 - In a landmark decision, the Supreme Court of Canada has reshaped the landscape of immigration law...
posts.author: GGI
posts.body:
Canada, September 27, 2023 - In a landmark decision, the Supreme Court of Canada has reshaped the landscape of immigration law, emphasizing fairness and limiting the power of immigration officials in the process. This significant ruling carries far-reaching implications for foreign nationals seeking refuge in the country.

The case at the heart of this legal precedent, Mason v Canada (Citizenship and Immigration), revolved around two foreign nationals, Earl Mason and Seifeslam Dleiow, both residing in Canada. Mr. Mason faced charges of attempted murder and firearm discharge following a barroom altercation, though these charges were later dropped due to delays in the legal process. Mr. Dleiow, on the other hand, was alleged to have engaged in acts of violence against intimate partners, with some charges dropped and others resulting in guilty pleas.

In response to these incidents, the Canada Border Services Agency (CBSA) prepared reports asserting that both men were inadmissible to Canada, citing s. 34(1)(e) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA).

Section 34(1)(e) of the IRPA defines inadmissibility on security grounds as 'engaging in acts of violence that would or might endanger the lives or safety of persons in Canada,' without specifying a requirement for a connection to national security or the security of Canada.

The inadmissibility tribunal interpreted 'acts of violence' under section 34(1)(e) broadly, extending its scope beyond the realm of national security. This meant that even though the violent conduct of both men posed no threat to national security, it was still sufficient to deem them inadmissible to Canada.

Dissenting from this decision, both Mr. Mason and Mr. Dleiow appealed, eventually reaching the highest judicial authority in the land - the Supreme Court.

In a decisive ruling, the Supreme Court clarified that a person can only be found inadmissible under section 34(1)(e) of the IRPA if their violent conduct is linked to national security or the security of Canada. As neither Mr. Mason nor Mr. Dleiow were alleged to have engaged in acts of violence with such connections, section 34(1)(e) did not provide a basis for their inadmissibility.

This verdict, according to immigration advocates and legal experts, reinforces the need for a precise and stringent interpretation of security inadmissibility provisions. It serves as a check on authorities and government tribunals, ensuring that the net is not cast too wide, and that decisions regarding deportation are based on well-founded and justifiable grounds.

This ruling exemplifies Canada's ongoing commitment to maintaining a fair and equitable immigration system, where every individual is considered on their individual merits and in accordance with the law. It marks a significant step towards achieving a balance between national security concerns and the rights of foreign nationals seeking a fresh start in the True North.

In the vibrant spirit of Canada, three provinces are rolling out the welcome mat for fresh nominees through the Provincial Nominee Program (PNP). Established in 1998, this program is the driving force behind provincial governments' efforts to handpick economic immigration candidates who are poised to make a lasting impact on the local labour force and economy.

Provincial Nominee Program: A Dynamic Partnership

The PNP's strength lies in its dynamic collaboration between federal and provincial governments. While candidates nominated by provinces must still take the separate route of applying for permanent resident status through Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC), this nomination holds immense promise. It significantly boosts the odds of getting the green light for permanent residence.

This advantage becomes even more electrifying for candidates in the federal Express Entry pool. Securing a provincial nomination automatically injects an extra dose of energy with an additional 600 points via the Comprehensive Ranking System (CRS). This game-changing boost virtually guarantees an Invitation to Apply (ITA) in an upcoming round of invitations. Notably, the minimum CRS score for ITAs in 2023 has consistently remained below 791, adding to the excitement.

Provincial Immigration Highlights: September 30 - October 5

British Columbia: British Columbia, renowned for its regular BC Provincial Nominee Program (BC PNP) draws, turned up the energy by inviting 110 candidates in a general draw on October 4. This all-inclusive draw made everyone feel part of the action, with no specific occupations targeted. Minimum scores for invitations danced to their own tunes, with Skilled Workers needing 111 points, International Graduates requiring 113, and Entry-Level and Semi-Skilled candidates setting the stage with 91 points. To keep the tempo going, three additional draws for Skilled Worker and International Graduate candidates required a minimum score of 60.

Alberta: On October 3, Alberta lit up the immigration scene by nominating 33 candidates through the Alberta Advantage Immigration Program (AAIP). These shining stars were selected from the Priority sector - Agriculture occupation with Alberta job offers, and all of them were Express Entry candidates. They were truly in tune with the rhythm, as a minimum CRS score of 313 was needed for nomination. This draw marked the debut of category-based Express Entry draws, bringing a fresh beat to the immigration landscape and streamlining candidates into roles aligned with the most urgent job vacancies.

Prince Edward Island: On October 5, Prince Edward Island cranked up the energy by extending invitations to 20 candidates through the Labour and Express Entry category of the PEI PNP. These rising stars were rocking it in the healthcare and food processing sectors. Since July, PEI has been setting the stage for targeted draws, taking center stage with a total of 505 candidates invited. They've been hitting all the right notes by focusing primarily on healthcare, food processing, manufacturing, construction, and undefined critical workers.

These developments exemplify Canada's unwavering commitment to immigration and economic growth, creating an energetic stage where talented individuals from around the world take the spotlight and become an integral part of the nation's prosperity.

posts.title: Bringing Loved Ones Closer: Canada's Parent and Grandparent Sponsorship Program
posts.description: Canada, a nation known for its warm and inclusive spirit, continues to open its arms to families wanting to unite with their parents...
posts.author: GGI
posts.body:
Canada, a nation known for its warm and inclusive spirit, continues to open its arms to families wanting to unite with their parents and grandparents through the Parents and Grandparents Program (PGP). This program not only allows your loved ones to become Canadian permanent residents but also paves the way for potential Canadian citizenship.

Here's what you need to know to make this dream a reality:

Eligibility Criteria

To be eligible for the PGP, sponsors must meet the following requirements:

  • Be a Canadian citizen, permanent resident of Canada, or a registered Indian under the Canadian Indian Act.
  • Be 18 years of age or older.
  • Reside in Canada.
    • Exceed the minimum necessary income level (MNI) for this program and provide proof of income to IRCC.
  • Sign an undertaking to financially support the sponsored person for 20 years and to repay any social assistance benefits paid to the sponsored family members for a period of 20 years.

Details for the 2023 PGP have not been released yet, but historically, the program's information has been unveiled in September or October.

Bringing Families Together: PGP in Action*

In 2022, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC) invited a whopping 23,100 potential sponsors to apply for their parents and grandparents' sponsorship, with a goal to receive 15,000 complete applications. This shows the tremendous interest and success of the program in reuniting families.

Canada's Immigration Levels Plan

Each year, IRCC releases an Immigration Levels Plan that guides its operations. In 2023, Canada aims to welcome 465,000 new permanent residents, followed by 485,000 in 2024 and 500,000 in 2025. Under the PGP, IRCC's target is to welcome 28,500 newcomers in 2023, 34,000 in 2024, and 36,000 in 2025. This reaffirms Canada's commitment to family reunification.

Introducing the Super Visa

For those seeking a more immediate option, there's the Super Visa – a temporary visa designed for Canadian citizens and permanent residents looking to bring their foreign parents and grandparents to Canada. Unlike the PGP, there's no lottery for the Super Visa, offering greater certainty to families.

The Super Visa allows parents and grandparents to visit their family for up to five consecutive years without renewing their visitor status. Holders can enter Canada multiple times for up to 10 years. For those already with a Super Visa, an extension is possible, potentially allowing them to remain in Canada as a visitor for up to seven years.

Who's Eligible for the Super Visa?

To be eligible for the Super Visa, applicants must:

  • Be a parent or grandparent of a Canadian citizen or permanent resident.
  • Not be inadmissible to Canada based on criminality or health.
  • Demonstrate the ability to meet income requirements identified by the Low-Income Cut Off (LICO).
  • Provide a signed letter from their child or grandchild inviting them to Canada, including a promise of financial support and household details.
  • Show proof of medical insurance coverage for at least one year with a Canadian insurance company.

The Super Visa is especially convenient for parents and grandparents living in countries requiring a Temporary Resident Visa (TRV) to enter Canada. With a Super Visa, they can travel freely between Canada and their home country without the need for re-applying for a TRV.

A Warm Welcome Awaits

Canada's commitment to family reunification remains unwavering, providing multiple avenues for parents and grandparents to be with their loved ones. Whether through the PGP or the Super Visa, the goal is clear – to bring families closer together in the true spirit of Canadian hospitality.

posts.title: Canada's Start-Up Visa Program: Your Path to Entrepreneurial Success
posts.description: Canada, a land known for its welcoming embrace of immigrants, beckons entrepreneurs to turn their dreams into reality through...
posts.author: GGI
posts.body:
Canada, a land known for its welcoming embrace of immigrants, beckons entrepreneurs to turn their dreams into reality through the Start-Up Visa Program (SUVP). This program opens doors for entrepreneurs and key figures within their businesses to establish, operate, and thrive in Canada's vibrant business landscape. The SUVP offers business owners permanent residence in Canada, provided their businesses can create jobs, foster innovation, compete globally. Even if challenges arise, successful applicants retain their PR status, a testament to Canada's commitment to fostering innovation and growth.

Who Qualifies for the SUVP?

Eligibility is the first step on the journey. To be considered, you must own a qualifying business, with at least 10% ownership of voting rights. All owners (up to five) and the designated Canadian investment organization must collectively own at least 50% of voting rights.

Eligible individuals must then meet these criteria:

  1. Designated Organization Support: Sponsorship and support from a designated Canadian organization.
  2. Language Proficiency: Proficiency in English or French, Canada's official languages.
  3. Sufficient Settlement Funds: Financial means to settle and live in Canada.
  4. Security and Medical Clearances: Successful immigration security and medical clearance checks.

The Vital Role of Designated Organizations

Support from a designated organization is a prerequisite, often including proof of funding. These organizations are government-approved to invest in or support start-ups. They provide entrepreneurs with a crucial letter of support, a critical part of the PR application. The designated organization sends a commitment certificate to IRCC, outlining their support and expectations.

Support and sponsorship can come from multiple organizations simultaneously, known as syndication.

Financial Backing: Proof of Funding Requirements

While entrepreneurs don't need to invest their own money, proof of funding is required, based on support from a venture capital firm or angel investor group. Sponsorship from a business incubator eliminates the need for proof of funding.

  • For venture capital group sponsorship, CAD $200,000 in confirmed funding must be demonstrated.
  • For angel investor group sponsorship, CAD $75,000 in confirmed funding must be shown.
  • In cases of multiple sponsorships, the higher criteria apply.

Ensuring a Smooth Journey

A peer review ensures adherence to SUVP protocols. Applicants must prove sufficient funds and language proficiency at a Canadian Language Benchmark (CLB) level of 5 in English or French. Rigorous security and medical clearance checks are standard. Applicants under the SUVP can obtain temporary work permits to work in Canada.

Canada: Your Entrepreneurial Oasis

Canada welcomes aspiring entrepreneurs with open arms and boundless opportunities, standing as a beacon of hope in the world of innovation and entrepreneurship.

Canada Tops the Charts: Ideal for Immigrant Entrepreneurs

According to the OECD, Canada leads the pack among all OECD countries, offering a favourable business environment, welcoming society, and excellent living conditions. Canada offers various immigration pathways and work permits, with the Start-Up Visa program leading the way, driving economic growth and job creation.

Canada beckons you to shape your future, contribute to a thriving economy, and become part of a diverse, innovative nation. The Canadian entrepreneurial adventure awaits!

posts.title: Unleashing Belonging: Immigrant Bonds with Canada
posts.description: Get ready for a thrilling exploration of how immigrants in Canada connect with their adopted homeland! The 2020 General...
posts.author: GGI
posts.body:
Get ready for a thrilling exploration of how immigrants in Canada connect with their adopted homeland! The 2020 General Social Survey (GSS), powered by Statistics Canada (StatsCan), offers a dynamic peek into where immigrants across the nation feel the strongest sense of belonging.

Ontario and Atlantic Canada: A Resounding Sense of Belonging

Picture this: Ontario and the Atlantic Canadian provinces (Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island, Newfoundland and Labrador, and New Brunswick) light up the immigrant belonging radar! In these provinces, newcomers shout from the rooftops about their deep-rooted connection to Canada.

British Columbia and Alberta: A Fascinating Contrast

Now, let's head west to the provinces of British Columbia and Alberta. Here, the immigrant experience is a bit different. The sense of belonging, while present, may not be as overwhelming. But why this regional variation?

Factors That Fuel Immigrant Belonging

Belonging isn't just an emotion; it's a complex interplay of factors that ignite the immigrant journey:

  1. Post-Migration Experiences: Immigrants measure their belonging by the positive vibes they get from their surroundings. Acceptance and opportunities are their fuel.
  2. Immigrant Sociodemographics: The immigrant journey is influenced by factors like the years since immigration, age at immigration, immigration category, and population group. The longer they're in Canada, the stronger their ties become.
  3. Immigrant Composition: Each province has its immigrant population mix. Provinces with more seasoned immigrants often boast a more profound sense of belonging, a bond forged over time.
  4. Feelings of Acceptance/Discrimination: The immigrant experience is coloured by discrimination or acceptance within their communities. A chilly reception can dampen belonging, while a warm embrace ignites it.
  5. Structural Factors/Context: Economic opportunities, education, and overall socio-economic conditions in a province play a pivotal role. Believing they can thrive and contribute fuels the sense of belonging.

Exploring the Results

The GSS data paints a vivid picture of immigrant belonging by province:

  • Immigrants in Ontario and the Atlantic provinces report a robust sense of belonging.
  • Immigrant composition in Alberta partly explains the difference in reported belonging between Alberta and Ontario.
  • British Columbia stands out as immigrants there report a weaker sense of belonging, even after accounting for various factors.

This study offers valuable insights into the complex interplay of factors that influence immigrants' feelings of belonging in different Canadian provinces. It's a testament to Canada's diverse and inclusive society, where fostering a sense of home for newcomers remains a top priority. As the nation continues to welcome immigrants with open arms, the shared journey of belonging to this beautiful land continues to evolve.

posts.title: Discover Your Path to Canadian Immigration: What Really Counts as Eligible Work Experience for Express Entry?
posts.description: Are you dreaming of a new life in Canada through the Express Entry system but unsure if your work experience qualifies?
posts.author: GGI
posts.body:
Are you dreaming of a new life in Canada through the Express Entry system but unsure if your work experience qualifies? The road to Canadian immigration is paved with specific criteria, and the type of work experience you possess can be the game-changer in your journey. Buckle up, because we're about to break down the nitty-gritty of what truly counts as eligible work experience for Express Entry!

Federal Skilled Worker Program (FSWP): The Gold Standard

Under the FSWP, you've got to prove that you've toiled away in a job that falls under the National Occupation Classification (NOC) categories TEER 0, TEER 1, TEER 2, or TEER 3. But that's not all. You must have performed all the essential duties and most of the main duties listed in the NOC occupational description. Oh, and did we mention it should be a paid gig with wages or earned commission? Plus, you need a solid year of continuous work (1,560 hours total) in the last 10 years. No room for volunteer-based stints or unpaid internships here!

Special Student Provisions: Unlocking Hidden Gems

If you were a student and meet three conditions - getting paid, maintaining continuous employment, and meeting all other FSWP eligibility requirements - your student work experience might just count towards your application!

Canadian Experience Class (CEC): Embrace Your Canadian Journey

CEC candidates need at least one year of skilled work experience in occupations falling under TEER 0, TEER 1, TEER 2, or TEER 3, but there's a twist – it must have been gained exclusively in the Great White North. This work should be fresh, completed in the three years before your application submission, and performed while you were authorized under temporary resident status. And remember, it should be paid work – volunteer gigs and unpaid internships won't cut it!

Ineligible Work Experience: Self-Employment and Student Life

Sorry, self-employed and full-time student days won't help you meet the CEC eligibility requirements. Those experiences won't give you a ticket to your Canadian dream!

Special Provisions for Physicians: Breaking the Mold

Physicians, listen up! If you're a self-employed foreign national physician providing publicly funded medical services in Canada, there's an exemption for you. Just don't check the 'self-employed work' box when creating your Express Entry profile, and you're on your way to immigration success!

Federal Skilled Trades Program (FSTP): Carve Your Path

Under the FSTP, it's all about having two years of full-time (or equivalent part-time) work experience in a skilled trade within the last five years. You've got to prove that you've handled all the duties in the NOC description, including the essential ones. And of course, it should be a paid gig, with no room for volunteer work or unpaid internships. Plus, you need to be qualified to independently practice your trade occupation during that time.

Eligible NOC Groups for FSTP: Find Your Fit

Your FSTP work experience should fall within one of these eight NOC groups:

  • Major Group 72: Technical trades and transportation officers and controllers (excluding Sub-Major Group 726)
  • Major Group 73: General trades
  • Major Group 82: Supervisors in natural resources, agriculture, and related production
  • Major Group 83: Occupations in natural resources and related production
  • Major Group 92: Processing, manufacturing, and utilities supervisors, and utilities operators and controllers
  • Major Group 93: Central control and process operators and aircraft assemblers and inspectors (excluding Sub-Major Group 932)
  • Minor Group 6320: Cooks, butchers, and bakers
  • Unit Group 62200: Chefs

Now that you know the ins and outs of eligible work experience for Express Entry, you're one step closer to your Canadian dream. Don't miss out on your chance to make it happen – the clock is ticking, and Canada awaits your arrival!

posts.title: Shocking Revelation: 94% of Employers Pass the TFWP Test! Are You Playing by the Rules?
posts.description: In a riveting turn of events, the latest findings from Employment and Social Development Canada (ESDC) have sent shockwaves...
posts.author: GGI
posts.body:
In a riveting turn of events, the latest findings from Employment and Social Development Canada (ESDC) have sent shockwaves through the nation. Brace yourself for the most astonishing compliance report of the year!

ESDC's Eye-Opening Discovery

Picture this: ESDC has just unveiled its in-depth investigation results for the 2022-2023 fiscal year. What they uncovered will leave you gasping for breath. Hold on tight, because here comes the bombshell—the compliance rate among the 2,100 employers surveyed stands at a staggering 94%! Yes, you read that right—94% of employers are acing the Temporary Foreign Worker Program (TFWP) regulations.

But what about the remaining 6%? You won't believe where they've ended up—on the Immigration Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC) website, exposed for all to see.

ESDC's Critical Role

ESDC, the watchdog for the welfare of Temporary Foreign Workers (TFWs), takes its mission seriously. Their job is to ensure employers hiring TFWs are playing by the rules of the TFWP. And they're doing it with astounding success!

Cracking Down on Non-Compliance

But wait, there's more! Among the handful of employers found non-compliant (a mere 6%), serious consequences are being meted out. Brace yourself for this:

  • 93 employers are being made to pay monetary penalties.
  • 23 employers have received stern warnings.
  • And a whopping 7 employers are now banned from participating in the program, some facing bans as long as five years!

High Stakes for Offenders

Two employers in the transport sector have been slapped with fines that will make your jaw drop—over $100,000 each! Why? For failing to provide fair wages and safe working conditions. And that's not all—a construction company had to cough up a whopping $53,000! It's a clear message: cutting corners comes at a heavy price.

The Winds of Change

This bombshell report comes in the wake of new regulations introduced to the TFWP in 2022. ESDC is revolutionizing the game, enhancing the program's inspection capabilities and ensuring that employers adhere to the rules with an iron grip.

Government's Commitment to Transparency

The government has pledged transparency moving forward. ESDC will now provide semi-annual updates on TFWP compliance efforts. This transparency will empower potential employees to identify reputable companies that play by the rules.

Navigating the Regulations

Before you dive into the details, here's a quick rundown of what these regulations entail:

  • Employers must secure a Labour Market Impact Assessment (LMIA) from ESDC, proving that hiring TFWs benefits Canada's economy.
  • TFWs are granted closed work permits, restricting them to one Canadian employer.
  • Employers must adhere to Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR), ensuring fair wages, safety, and well-being.
  • Compliance means providing suitable accommodation, following health protocols (including COVID-19 rules), and preventing employee abuse.
  • Employers must also pay TFWs according to a low-wage or high-wage scale, depending on the situation.

Caps and Restrictions

To reduce reliance on TFWs, the Government of Canada has imposed caps on low-wage temporary foreign workers. For instance, businesses with 10 or more employees are now limited to 10% of their workforce being low-wage temporary foreign workers. Some low-wage occupations may even be refused for LMIA processing.

Incentives for the Law-Abiding

But hold on to your hats! ESDC has recently introduced the Recognized Employer Pilot (REP) program. This program is a game-changer for repeat TFWP employers with a track record of compliance. The perks include reduced administrative work and 36-month LMIA validity, among others.

According to ESDC, the benefits are astounding:

  • A simplified application process for future LMIA applications for positions on the Canadian Occupational Projection System (COPS) list.
  • Fewer points of contact with ESDC due to simplified LMIA forms.
  • A coveted Job Bank designation, signaling their recognized status to attract top-notch talent.

posts.title: Supreme Court of Canada Refines Immigration Security Criteria
posts.description: In a groundbreaking verdict that promises to reshape the landscape of immigration law, the Supreme Court of Canada has issued a...
posts.author: GGI
posts.body:
In a groundbreaking verdict that promises to reshape the landscape of immigration law, the Supreme Court of Canada has issued a ruling that narrows the scope of immigration authorities and tribunals in their ability to expel foreign nationals on security grounds, particularly those with no previous criminal convictions. The case in question, Mason v Canada (Citizenship and Immigration), revolves around Earl Mason and Seifeslam Dleiow, foreign nationals residing in Canada. This decision sets a significant precedent in delineating the limits of admissibility.

The Cases in Focus

Earl Mason initially faced charges of attempted murder and firearm discharge following an altercation in a bar. Ultimately, these charges were dismissed due to legal process delays. In the case of Seifeslam Dleiow, allegations of violence against intimate partners emerged. While some of these charges were dropped, Dleiow pled guilty to three others. Both cases prompted the Canada Border Services Agency (CBSA) to prepare reports asserting that these individuals were inadmissible under section 34(1)(e) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA).

The Contested Section 34(1)(e)

Section 34(1)(e) of the IRPA defines inadmissibility on security grounds as engaging in acts of violence that could endanger the lives or safety of individuals in Canada. The crux of the matter centered on the interpretation of 'acts of violence' within this section. The inadmissibility tribunal had previously interpreted it broadly, without necessitating a direct link to national security or the security of Canada. This meant that the violent behavior of Mason and Dleiow, despite not posing a national security threat, was sufficient to render them inadmissible.

The Supreme Court's Clarification

Mason and Dleiow contested these decisions, eventually leading to the Supreme Court's intervention. In a landmark ruling, the Court clarified that a person can only be found inadmissible under section 34(1)(e) if their violent conduct is explicitly linked to national security or the security of Canada. Since neither Mason nor Dleiow were alleged to have engaged in violent acts connected to these national security aspects, section 34(1)(e) did not provide a valid basis for their inadmissibility.

Implications and Responses

This pivotal decision, according to immigration advocates and legal experts, will constrain the authority of authorities and government tribunals from casting an excessively wide net to target individuals for deportation. It underscores the need for a precise and proportionate connection between violent behavior and national security concerns when contemplating inadmissibility.

In essence, the Supreme Court's ruling underscores the importance of clarity and equity in immigration decisions, safeguarding the rights of foreign nationals while upholding Canada's security interests. The verdict is poised to have a lasting impact on the comprehension and application of security-related inadmissibility provisions, contributing to a more transparent and accountable immigration system in Canada.

Canada's Finance Minister, Chrystia Freeland, has unveiled an exciting plan aimed at enhancing affordability across the country. Introducing Bill C-56, known as the Affordable Housing and Groceries Act, this comprehensive legislation encompasses several initiatives designed to put more money back into the hands of Canadians while fostering vibrant competition in crucial sectors.

Pioneering Affordable Housing Solutions

At the heart of Bill C-56 lies an adjustment to the Excise Tax Act, poised to have a transformative impact on affordable housing. Under this fresh legal framework, an enhancement to the GST New Residential Rental Property Rebate seeks to invigorate builders to invest in the development of new rental properties. The objective is crystal clear: to supercharge the supply of rental accommodations in Canada and, in doing so, drive down rental costs.

So, what's the boon for builders? It's substantial news. The revamped GST Rental Rebate elevates the rebate rate from a modest 36 per cent to an impressive 100 per cent, liberating the previous phase-out thresholds and streamlining the qualification process for new rental housing projects. This bold initiative is set to make renting more financially feasible for Canadians, especially in major urban centers where rental expenses have surged.

Alleviating Rental Pressures

For many Canadians and newcomers alike, the dream of homeownership has appeared increasingly unattainable due to the shortage of reasonably priced housing. With the average cost of a home surpassing $600,000, as reported by the Canadian Real Estate Association, the prospect of owning a house has remained elusive for many. The average cost of renting a one-bedroom apartment in Canada stands at $2,117. This substantial financial burden has posed a significant challenge for newcomers to Canada, who often require rental housing as they embark on their new journeys.

Empowering Equitable Competition

Bill C-56 goes beyond addressing housing concerns; it also introduces crucial modifications to the Competition Act, with the aim of fostering a fairer and more competitive marketplace. These adjustments empower the Competition Bureau to take action when industries engage in unfair practices, such as price manipulation and unwarranted price increases—matters that directly impact consumers' finances.

The removal of the 'efficiencies defense'g is another significant stride forward. This signifies a commitment to curtailing anti-competitive mergers that lead to higher prices and fewer choices for Canadian consumers. With this alteration, the Competition Bureau gains the authority to obstruct collaborations that hinder competition and consumer options.

By preventing mergers and partnerships that stifle competition, Canada is nurturing an environment where prices either remain competitive or decrease to attract and retain customers. This not only benefits consumers but also encourages businesses to provide superior services at affordable rates.

In conclusion, Canada's Affordable Housing and Groceries Act, encapsulated in Bill C-56, represents a forward-thinking, resolute move toward a more affordable and competitive future. It seeks to make housing more accessible, particularly for newcomers, while championing fair competition to the delight of consumers. With these initiatives in place, Canadians can anticipate a brighter and more budget-friendly future.

posts.title: Unlocking Opportunities: Post-Graduate Work Permit Programs in Canada

posts.body:
Canada has become a top destination for international students seeking quality education and a boost into their preferred dream careers. These international students have the opportunity to obtain a Post-Graduate Work Permit to help them kick start their professional life in Canada. In this blog, we’ll explore the benefits, eligibility criteria, and application process for PGWP programs in Canada. If you’re a recent graduate from a DLI in Canada, you may want to pay attention.

What is a PGWP Program?

A PGWP is a permit that allows students who graduated from eligible Canadian designated learning institutions (DLIs) to obtain an open work permit. With this permit, it allows them to gain valuable Canadian work experience, and when it is gained through the PGWP Program, graduates are able to qualify for permanent residency in Canada through Express Entry.

[Express entry is an application process for skilled immigrants who want to settle in Canada permanently and take part in the economy. A designated learning institution (DLI) is a school approved by a provincial or territorial government to host international students.]

Now, “experience” is quite a broad term and does not specify what exactly can be classified as relevant experience. This is why we categorize experience in Training, Education, Experience, and Responsibilities (i.e., TEER), within categories 0, 1, 2, or 3.

These permits are also exempt from LMIAs, which, as stated in a previous blog, is a document that employers in Canada may need to get before hiring a foreign worker. With a PGWP, graduates can work full-time, part-time, or be self-employed.

Application Process

The first step in the application process is ensuring that you apply within 180 days of obtaining written confirmation. The application package is obtained through the IRCC website, within and outside of Canada. Two confirming documents that are required are, of course, the letter confirming the completion of study, as well as the transcript.

Things to Consider

There are a few things to take note of before looking to apply for a PGWP. This can include whether or not you graduated from a designated learning institution (DLI), if you completed school via distance learning, or other factors that would make you ineligible for a PGWP.

Why Choose PGWP?

Picture a PGWP as your gateway to the working world, transitioning from and bridging the gap between being an international student to a working employee. This open work permit not only allows for flexibility, but also allows you to gain highly valued Canadian work experience. But, the journey does not stop there: having a PGWP helps you transition into the next stage of your career and creates a pathway to permanent residency. With a possibility of obtaining a PGWP of up to three years, this extended stay allows you to continue building your career and exploring your options in Canada.

Refusal of a Canada visa is the biggest obstacle for individuals who want to study, work, and settle in Canada. Numerous applicants seeking entry to Canada are denied visas each year. There are different reasons your Canadian visa application could be denied. 


So without further ado, let's look at the top five reasons why Canada denies visa applications.


1. FAILURE TO PROVIDE ENOUGH SUPPORTING DOCUMENTS When applying for a Canadian visa, applicants will be required to submit supporting documents demonstrating that they have not provided false information. Students applying for a study permit, for instance, are required to submit a copy of their degree and transcripts. Professionals, on the other hand, must submit a reference letter detailing their work experience, hours worked, and responsibilities when applying for a work visa to Canada. Your visa could be denied if you don't provide enough evidence to back up your claims.


2. INSUFFICIENT EVIDENCE TO PROVE YOU CAN SUPPORT YOURSELF FINANCIALLY   

Whether you are going to Canada for studying, working, or traveling, you will need to provide sufficient proof that you will not be a liability to Canada. You will be required to demonstrate your ability to support yourself and any accompanying family members during your stay in Canada. Your Canadian visa application may be denied if you are unable to provide the necessary documentation to support your claim. Every international student applying for a study visa to Canada must demonstrate their financial stability. They can achieve this by offering: If they have transferred money to Canada, evidence of a Canadian bank account in their name, a student or education loan from a bank, a Guaranteed Investment Certificate (GIC) from a participating Canadian financial institution, and proof that they have paid tuition and housing fees. Students applying for a student visa to Canada can check here how much they need to live on.


3. Inability to demonstrate your intention to return to your home country 

When applying for a tourist visa or student visa, applicants must keep in mind that the visa is only temporary and has an expiration date. As a result, applicants are required to provide sufficient evidence of their intention to return to their home nation. They will not remain in Canada after their visa expires if they provide evidence. A visa official might dismiss your application on the off chance that he is unconvinced that you will get back to your country toward your approved stay's end. You can provide certified translations of lease agreements for your property to demonstrate your intention to return to your home nation. Let's say you're a worker traveling to Canada as a tourist. If that's the case, you can provide an employment letter stating that you are a permanent employee of the company. You can also provide documentation stating the anticipated return date to your employment.


4. Lack of evidence indicating good health:

Applicants who intend to stay in Canada for at least six months are required to undergo a medical examination. A medical exam may or may not be required for those who stay for less than six months. It depends on what they intend to accomplish. The purpose of these medical examinations is to ensure that the applicant: Does not have an infectious disease that is currently active, such as syphilis or tuberculosis, which can pose a threat to public health. Do not experience a loss of physical and mental abilities, unpredictability, or violent behavior, which can pose a threat to public safety. If the applicant is unable to pass the medical exam and demonstrate that he is in good health, his visa may be denied.


5. Moving on to the next reason why a visa was denied, the visa officer was not convinced that you intended to visit Canada. It stems from the applicant's inability to demonstrate to visa officers that he intends to travel to Canada. Immigration authorities require confirmation that your travel plans to Canada are legal and constructive. You'll need to show that you won't stay too long and are only visiting for tourism like to attend a conference or meet your family. Let's say the visa officer doesn't like your reason for going to Canada. He might deny your visa application to Canada in that case. Your previous travel experiences, such as overstaying in another country, may also have an impact on his decision. 


Conclusion: Rejecting a visa can discourage applicants and make it more difficult to apply for another visa in Canada. These are the top five reasons for Canada visa refusal, though there are many other possible explanations. Therefore, the takeaway is to keep them in mind when you apply for your visa at the following time. If you want to reapply for a visa, you can get assistance from our skilled immigration consultant to avoid any problems with the application process.

WHY IS THE CRS SCORE FOR EXPRESS ENTRY DECREASING?


Before kickstarting with the why’s and hows, let's try to fathom what CRS score is and how important of a role it plays. The Express Entry Comprehensive Ranking System (CRS) score is used to rank you among hundreds of thousands of people awaiting an Invitation to Apply (ITA) for permanent residency in the Express Entry pool. 


No minimum CRS score is required to be included in the Express Entry pool. All you need is to be eligible for one of the 3 immigration programs that use Express Entry; Canadian Experience Class, Federal Skilled Worker, and Federal Skilled Trades (FST). However, since Express Entry is a points-based system, a higher CRS score means a higher chance of immigrating to Canada.


It’s used to assess your:


  1. skills

  2. education

  3. language ability

  4. work experience

  5. other factors


Since the start of all-program draws on July 6th, the CRS score has been steadily declining, as we have observed with prior Express Entry draws. Since every program attracts applications, 7,500 applicants have received ITAs; this number is anticipated to rise.


Each draw has seen an increase in the number of candidates invited, although the CRS cut-off score has continuously decreased as the backlog of applications in the system is being processed. A 9-point drop from 525 to 516 in the previous draw was seen in the most recent draw. In the 230th draw, ITAs were awarded to an extra 2,750 applicants.


The following draws are anticipated to see a further decline in the CRS score. Canada will start accepting candidates based on merit starting in the first quarter of 2023.


The immigration minister will be able to invite candidates based on groupings rather than just CRS ratings under Bill C-19, which was unveiled earlier this year. Combinations of work experience in a sought-after occupation or set of occupations, linguistic ability, and educational background may be grouped together. The CRS cut-off is expected to be substantially lower compared to the general draws that we have been witnessing lately because candidates will be judged against those in their group rather than the whole Express Entry pool.

New Canadian TEER System The new NOC system (TEER) was announced in 2020 and made public at the beginning of 2021.TEER, or training, education, experience, and responsibility classification, is the name of the new system. By the middle of early 2022, we can anticipate that IRCC will start implementing this change. The National Occupational Classification (NOC) system undergoes major structural revisions every ten years, which is why this change is taking place. As a result of this change, information from numerous relevant stakeholders and the existing occupational groups is examined.

Statistics Canada, the IRCC, and job seekers (both domestic and international) would be the primary stakeholders in this change. The TEER classification, or updated system, was developed in response to Canada's current economic climate.


The NOC is Canada's public word-related reference. It classifies employment activities in Canada to help understand how the Canadian labor market is structured, run government programs, encourage skill development, conduct research, and help Canada manage its immigration and foreign worker programs.

Every ten years, the federal government conducts a comprehensive review of the NOC. Consequently, the NOC is updated to reflect the Canadian labor market and economic changes. Statistics Canada and Employment and Social Development Canada (ESDC) launched NOC 2021 in September.NOC 2021 is the climax of an extensive interaction that incorporates a thorough review, investigation, and assessment of the Canadian economy.

Currently, NOC 2016 is used by Employment and Social Development Canada (ESDC), Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC), and Canada's provinces and territories to manage immigration and foreign worker programs. However, IRCC stated that NOC 2021 will be implemented in the fall of 2022 by both IRCC and ESDC. The federal government wants to give stakeholders, like people applying for immigration, more time to understand how NOC 2021 might affect them.


Its effect on immigrants and foreign workers NOC 2021 will have little to no effect on applications from immigrants and foreign workers.This is because their work experience will continue to meet the eligibility requirements for their preferred immigration or foreign worker program, despite changes to the NOC.However, some candidates will benefit from the changes while others will suffer.For instance, candidates may now be eligible for additional programs if their employment experience has changed.Alternately, others might find that they are as of now not qualified for a similar explanation.

Applications may be affected in a variety of ways at this time.Stakeholders will have to wait for IRCC and ESDC to provide additional details.The TEER system is taking the place of the skill type model, as stated by Statistics Canada, for two primary reasons.To begin, the TEER system aims to make it clear how much education and experience are required to work in a particular field.Second, Statistics Canada believes that the skill type approach leads to inaccurate distinctions between occupations with low and high levels of skill.Stakeholders should have a better understanding of the number of skills required for each job when TEER is implemented.

One of the Employer Job Offer streams of the Ontario Immigrant Nominee Program (OINP), a Provincial Nominee Program (PNP) run by the province of Ontario, is for international students. Foreign nationals with completed Canadian degrees and job offers from Ontario employers are the focus of the International Students stream.


Foreign workers with a job offer in a skilled occupation can apply to live and work permanently in Ontario through the Employer Job Offer: Foreign Worker stream.


Your employment offer must be in a skilled occupation at the National Occupational Classification's Skill Type 0 or Skill Level A or B. (NOC). Foreign employees both inside and outside of Canada are eligible for this stream.


Prerequisites for job offers

You must have a job offer from an employer in Ontario that satisfies the criteria listed below in order to be eligible under the Employer Job Offer: Foreign Worker stream.

1. Consistent and full-time

The offered position must be full-time and permanent.

Full-time employment requires at least 1,560 hours of the work year and 30 hours of paid work per week.

A permanent position must have no expiration date (also known as an indeterminate duration). Seasonal and/or contract-based job offers are not eligible.


2. Qualifying profession

The position being offered must be in a skilled occupation at the National Occupational Classification's Skill Type 0 or Skill Levels A or B. (NOC).


3. Median hourly pay

The salary for the position must be at least as high as the median wage for that occupation in the particular region of Ontario where you will be working.

4. The position is crucial to the employer's operations.

The role must be urgently required by the operations of your employer. This means that the position must be urgently needed in order to maintain or expand current business activity, and the employment offer must be compatible with your employer's current business operations.


5. Have a job in Ontario

The majority of the work you complete while holding the employment offer must take place in Ontario.
